awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Assignment to Evaluation: The Design of School Choice Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In the last decade, there has been a great deal of activity and excitement in market design, a small but growing  field of economics which studies how to design mechanisms and institutions through which individuals interact and also attempts to improve existing systems, recommends new mechanisms, and reports on their performance.  In particular, there has been progress in the study of student assignment systems, such as those found in choice plans in many public school districts in the United States and around the world.  The initial literature on these systems built on an earlier mechanism design and matching literature, while recent work has matured to a point where economists have been able to advise a handful of school districts on their allocation procedures.  To date, hundreds of thousands of students have been assigned to schools via new assignment mechanisms inspired by this work. Moreover, based on the persistence of these new mechanisms as well as summary measures of performance, the initial experience with these mechanisms has been promising.
This proposal outlines a long-term agenda of research and education on the design, implementation, and study of student assignment systems and school choice.  The proposal consists of three parts.  First, I will study important unresolved theoretical questions motivated by challenges in applying mechanisms in practice.  These include issues related to dynamics, efficiency in stochastic mechanisms, and the overall desirability of school choice.
Second, experiences and partnerships with school districts in Boston, Chicago, and New York provide me the opportunity to study how participants respond to the incentives of particular admissions rules.  This, in turn, will allow me to rigorously measure the distributional consequences of choice-based reforms. For example, using variation generated by policy changes from new mechanisms, I intend to study the nature and consequences of gaming among participants.  Do participants react to systems which create perverse incentives on participants to reveal their true preferences?  Do some sophisticated applicants gain from knowledge of particular admissions rules to the detriment of other unsophisticated applicants?  Another issue I will study is learning and information acquisition about mechanisms. How do applicants learn about good schools and how to best utilize choice options?  Answers to empirical questions about mechanisms in the field will ultimately lead to the design of better systems and to a deeper understanding of the interaction between mechanisms and their practical implementation.
Third, I will use my knowledge of student assignment procedures to exploit quasi-experimental variation to study long-standing questions on education production and school performance. For instance, I intend to study the causal effects of selective education, the impacts of peers and student grouping, and the influence of various school models on student achievement.   Which schools are best for which kids?  Do children benefit from being in schools with schools with peers of similar ability?  Does this stratification hurt lower performing students?  Studies using the rich new datasets developed in this proposal will enhance public policy debates and the economics of education.
This research naturally supports my education and outreach activities.  I will develop a new graduate course in market design, provide school districts assistance with their assignment algorithms, and bring together practitioners and researchers through an annual meeting on school assignment.
The expansion of knowledge on student assignment represents an important development and opportunity for market design within the discipline of economics.  Experiences implementing mechanisms in the field lead to new theoretical issues, policy questions, and empirical analyses.  The results and lessons derived from design exercises will foster the creation of a practically-oriented design literature to complement the existing theoretical literature on mechanism design.  Connections to school districts offer a unique opportunity to study long-standing empirical questions on education in innovative ways with new data sets and empirical approaches.
This project has a direct public benefit: it will help school districts design better student assignment mechanisms. It will also enhance policy makers' understanding of factors that impact student achievement.  Because of the importance of input from practitioners, a central component of the proposal is a conference hosted at the NBER involving academics and practitioners, intended to catalyze and disseminate scholarship related to best practices in student assignment.  I will also pursue a number of mentoring activities at the undergraduate and graduate level.

por.por_cntn:
In the past two decades, education policymakers in cities across the United States have adopted systems of school choice which leverage centralized assignment mechanisms that place students in schools. The focus of this research has been to design, implement, and study these systems of school choice. 

 

In one line of investigation, I studied important unresolved conceptual questions motivated by the practical challenges of adopting centralized assignment mechanisms. In a joint working paper with Abdulkadiro?lu, Che, Roth, and Tercieux, we examine New Orleans, where the school district was the first to use a mechanism based on Top Trading Cycles (TTC) in a real-life allocation problem (“Minimizing Justified Envy in School Choice: The Design of New Orleans' OneApp”). We show that, among all Pareto efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms, TTC minimizes justified envy when each school has one seat. Using data from New Orleans and Boston, we then show that TTC has significantly less justified envy compared to serial dictatorship.

 

I also worked in partnership with school districts across the country including Boston, Chicago, New Orleans, and New York to measure the distributional consequences of choice-based reforms. Using data from New York City, which adopted a deferred acceptance mechanism in 2003, Abdulkadiro?lu, Agarwal, and I fit econometric models of school demand. We use the estimates to quantify the distribution of student welfare and the aspects of school choice market design that are most important to allocative efficiency. We show that the new mechanism achieves 80 percent of the possible gains from a no-choice neighborhood extreme to a utilitarian benchmark. Students most likely to be previously administratively assigned experienced the largest gains in welfare and subsequent achievement. In other work in Boston, my co-authors Dur, Sönmez, and I find that the order in which different types of school seats are filled has meaningful effects on student assignment and is therefore a meaningful school admissions policy consideration for districts (our paper, “Reserve Design: Unintended Consequences and The Demise of Boston’s Walk Zones,” is forthcoming in the Journal of Political Economy). My other papers in Chicago and New Orleans similarly evaluate the design and consequences of school choice markets.

 

In a third line of work, I used my knowledge of market design and centralized assignment mechanisms to exploit the quasi-experimental variation inherent in choice systems to evaluate school performance. My co-authors Abdulkadiro?lu, Angrist, Narita and I published a paper in Econometrica outlining this pioneering methodology to evaluate Denver’s public schools, where we find that charter school attendance results in large achievement gains for students (“Research Design Meets Market Design: Using Centralized Assignment for Impact Evaluation”). These findings are relevant to both education policymakers and evaluators seeking a more rigorous approach to impact evaluation and can hold great potential for application within other centralized assignment systems, such as the U.S. medical match.

 

These results have been disseminated not only through publication but through deep engagement with academic, policy, and general audiences. This work has contributed to the development of a graduate-level course in market design at MIT and my involvement and coordination of an annual meeting on market design at the National Bureau of Economic Research. As part of this research I have mentored a number of junior researchers, including both undergraduate and graduate students. Beyond academia, I collaborated regularly with policymakers supervising the design and implementation of school choice systems across the country. These collaborations have contributed to greater understanding among policymakers of the implications of mechanism design for student access to schools and for student achievement and have additionally served as fruitful inspiration for new research topics. I further seek to disseminate my work through the MIT School Effectiveness and Inequality Initiative website (www.seii.mit.edu). Research findings supported by this grant have been featured in publications such as the New York Times and the Economist.

 

In summary, the research performed with this generous support from the National Science Foundation has contributed greater knowledge of the conceptual underpinnings of school choice systems and their implications for student access and achievement. This knowledge has impacted policymakers’ understanding of best practices for designing and implementing centralized assignment systems and has improved our collective understanding of systems of school choice.
